'Koreans in Japan' are the ethnic Korean residents of Japan. They currently
constitute the second largest ethnic group in Japan. The majority of Koreans in
Japan are 'Zainichi Koreans', also often known as 'Zainichi' (å¨æ¥) for short, who
are the permanent ethnic Korean residents of Japan. The term "Zainichi Korean"
refers only to long term Korean residents of Japan who trace their roots to the
period of Japanese colonialism in Korea, distinguishing them from the later wave
of Korean migrants who came mostly in the 1980s. }}

The Japanese word "Zainichi" itself means "staying in Japan", and implies
temporary residence. }} Nevertheless, the term "Zainichi Korean" is
used to describe settled permanent residents of Japan, both those who have
retained either their Joseon (old, undivided Korea) or South Korean
nationalities, and even sometimes includes 'Japanese citizens of Korean descent'
who acquired Japanese nationality by naturalization or by birth from one or both
parents who have Japanese citizenship.
